NYC Trees Analysis Xilin Huang & Pengfei Yan 2022-05-03 Chapter 1 Introduction As we know,the United States collects census data every ten years. By collecting the census data, the government could use the data to do some analysis and future adjustments. The census data provides us with plenty of information. “Tree canopy confers ecological, economic, and social benefits and can be used to enhance neighborhoods disproportionately affected by environmental challenges such as excessive heat, impervious surfaces, and air pollution.” Trees are valuable resources for our daily life. In New York city, the New York City Department of Parks & Recreation also collects the tree census every ten years from 1995. Up until now, we have the access toward three decades’ tree census data. This data information gives us opportunities to analyze the density change over these three decades. Trees’ health is strongly affected by neighbor. So, the trees’ health condition in the dataset can help us to determine the suitable tree species for different district with various surroundings. By collecting these three decades information about urban forest, we can compare the change of favorable tree species. In this report, we will use current available three decades of tree census data sets to do some deep analysis of the urban forest in New York.

Chapter 2 Data sources We decide to do some analysis about New York City. So we look for some data set about New York City that is available online. We find that there are a lot of valuable data sets on the website called NYC open data. After browsing available data sets on this website. We decide to do some analysis about the urban forest in New York City. The data sets that we are going to use are tree census from 1995, 2005 and 2015. Since all of these three data sets contains one tree information per row, these data sets are pretty large. For tree census 1995, the data set was created in 2015. And for tree census 2005 and 2015, these two data sets were created in 2016. Since the data was not created right after the tree census, there might be some missing values or missing columns while we compare these three data sets. Perhaps the 1995 tree census data set was created based on past record, so, the items that were recorded might differ from current standard. For the data set of tree census 1995, there are 517k rows and 30 columns. For the data set of tree census 2005, there are 592k rows and 54 columns. For the data set of tree census 2015, there are 684K rows and 45 columns. These data sets provides us very precise information about each trees. Our analysis is focus on overview of the urban forest. So, we will select several columns to do some data analysis and data visualization. Links for our data sources: https://data.cityofnewyork.us/Environment/1995-Street-Tree-Census/kyad-zm4j https://data.cityofnewyork.us/Environment/2005-Street-Tree-Census/29bw-z7pj https://data.cityofnewyork.us/Environment/2015-Street-Tree-Census-Tree-Data/uvpi-gqnh

So, we need to filter out useful columns for our analysis. For our analysis, we need the following variables: the ID of the tree, the name of tree’s species, the postcode of tree’s location, the borough of tree’s location and the diameter of stump.
